That settlement (announced August/September 2025, case filed 2024) is significant for a few key reasons:

**The money** — $1.5 billion is being called the largest copyright recovery in history. It works out to roughly $3,000 per downloaded book for ~500,000 titles.

**The legal split** — This is where it gets interesting. The judge actually ruled that *training* AI on copyrighted material *could be fair use* — but storing 7+ million pirated books in a "central library" was a separate violation. So Anthropic didn't admit liability for the training itself, just for the pirated copies they kept.

**What Anthropic has to do** — Destroy those downloaded book copies. They can still face claims over output from their models, but the training data archive has to go.

**The precedent** — It's the first settlement in this wave of AI copyright cases. OpenAI, Microsoft, and Meta still face similar lawsuits. The core "fair use" question isn't settled — it's being fought in other courts. A Meta case around the same time suggested using copyrighted work without permission would be unlawful "in many circumstances."

**For creators** — The Authors Guild called it a win, but realistically it shows the legal landscape is still murky. Training might be fair use, but *how* you acquire and store the data matters a lot.

The takeaway: AI companies can't just scrape pirate sites and archive everything indefinitely, even if the actual training process gets some fair-use protection.

**Lai Chee-ying** ([Chinese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters "Traditional Chinese characters"): 黎智英; born 8 December 1947[[2]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-2)), also known as **Jimmy Lai**, is a Hong Kong businessman, politician and [political prisoner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_prisoner "Political prisoner"). He founded [Giordano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giordano_(clothing) "Giordano (clothing)"), an Asian clothing retailer; [Next Digital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next_Digital "Next Digital") (formerly Next Media), a Hong Kong-listed media company; and the newspaper _[Apple Daily](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple\_Daily "Apple Daily")_. He is one of the main contributors to Hong Kong's [pro-democracy camp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pro-democracy_camp_(Hong_Kong) "Pro-democracy camp (Hong Kong)"), especially to the [Democratic Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Hong_Kong) "Democratic Party (Hong Kong)"). Although he is known as a Hong Kong political figure, he has been a [British citizen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Nationality_(Hong_Kong)_Selection_Scheme "British Nationality (Hong Kong) Selection Scheme") since 1994.[[3]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-3) He was imprisoned in 2020 and his business operations shuttered under Chinese government pressure.

A prominent critic of the [Chinese Communist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party "Chinese Communist Party") (CCP) who met with U.S. Vice President [Mike Pence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Pence "Mike Pence"), Secretary of State [Mike Pompeo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Pompeo "Mike Pompeo"), and National Security Advisor [John Bolton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Bolton "John Bolton") during the [Hong Kong protests of 2019–2020](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%932020_Hong_Kong_protests "2019–2020 Hong Kong protests"),[[4]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-4) Lai [was arrested](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Ransacking_of_Next_Media_Headquarter_by_the_Department_for_Safeguarding_National_Security "The Ransacking of Next Media Headquarter by the Department for Safeguarding National Security") on 10 August 2020 by the [Hong Kong Police Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong_Police_Force "Hong Kong Police Force") on charges of violating the territory's new national security law,[[5]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-5)[[6]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-6) an action which prompted widespread criticism.[[7]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-7)[[8]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-8)[[9]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-over100-9) Lai was allowed bail on 12 August, but on 3 December, Lai was accused of fraud and his bail was revoked. The court decided to jail Lai until April 2021, marking the first time Lai has been detained. Lai regarded his imprisonment as "the summit of his own life".[[10]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-10)

In 2020, Lai was awarded the "Freedom of Press Award" by [Reporters Without Borders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders "Reporters Without Borders") for his role in founding _Apple Daily_, a news outlet under Lai's pro-democracy leadership that "still dares to openly criticise the Chinese regime and which widely covered last year's pro-democracy protests."[[11]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-11)[[12]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-The_Case_of_Jimmy_Lai-12) That same month, Lai resigned from his roles with Next Digital as director and chairman of the board.[[13]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-13)[[14]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-14)

In April 2021, he was sentenced to an additional 14 months in prison for organising illegal protests.[[15]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-:2-15) As of September 2025, Lai remains imprisoned in [solitary confinement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solitary_confinement "Solitary confinement") at Hong Kong's [Stanley Prison](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanley_Prison "Stanley Prison").[[16]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-16) A motion for an [appeal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appeal "Appeal") was rejected in August 2024.[[17]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-17) He was found [guilty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HKSAR_v_Lai_Chee_Ying_%26_Others "HKSAR v Lai Chee Ying & Others") of national security offenses in December 2025 and sentenced to 20 years in prison in February 2026, a penalty [Human Rights Watch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch "Human Rights Watch") called "both cruel and profoundly unjust."[[18]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-18)[[19]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-19)

Lai was born in Canton ([Guangzhou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangzhou "Guangzhou")), [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912-1949) "Republic of China (1912-1949)"), on 8 December 1947 to a wealthy business family right before the Communist Party assumed power in the country [[20]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-20). At the age of 12, he entered Hong Kong as a stowaway on a boat.[[21]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-21) Upon his arrival, Lai began work as a child labourer in a garment factory for a wage of the equivalent of US$8 per month.[[22]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-22)

Lai's factory work saw him rise to the position of factory manager.[[23]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-:0-23) In 1975, Lai used his year-end bonus on Hong Kong stocks to raise cash and bought a bankrupt garment factory, Comitex, where he began producing and exporting sweaters.[[24]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-24) Customers included [J.C. Penney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J.C._Penney "J.C. Penney"), [Montgomery Ward](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montgomery_Ward "Montgomery Ward"), and other U.S. retailers.[[25]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-25)

In 1981, Lai founded Asian clothing retailer [Giordano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giordano_International "Giordano International").[[26]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-26) By rewarding sellers with financial incentives in Hong Kong, he built the chain into an Asia-wide retailer. Giordano was said to have more than 8,000 employees in 2,400 shops in 30 countries.[[27]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-27)

In 1996, Lai sold his stake in Giordano, leaving the garment industry for media and politics,[[28]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-28)[[29]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-29) keeping Comitex active as a shell company. Comitex, along with other private companies controlled by Lai, was reported to be the financial tools for his political activities and donations.[[30]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-30)

In 1997 Lai put up the capital for his twin sister, Si Wai, to acquire numerous properties in the Southern Ontario wine and vacation region of [Niagara-on-the-Lake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niagara-on-the-Lake "Niagara-on-the-Lake").[[31]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-31) The Lais Group of Companies now owns additional properties in [Caledon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caledon,_Ontario "Caledon, Ontario") and [Jordan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan,_Ontario "Jordan, Ontario"), both in Ontario.[[32]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-32) Lai remains the owner despite his arrest.[[33]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-33)

During the [dot-com boom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dot-com_bubble "Dot-com bubble") of the late 1990s, Lai started an Internet-based [grocery retailer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grocery_store "Grocery store") that offered home delivery services, adMart.[[34]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-34) The business expanded its product scope beyond groceries to include electronics and office supplies, but was shut down after losing between $100 and $150 million.[[35]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-35) Lai attributed this business failure to overconfidence and a lack of viable business strategy.[[36]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-autogenerated2-36)

In 2011, Next Media reportedly sold 70 per cent stake of Next Media's subsidiary Colored World Holdings (CWH, incorporated in the British Virgin Islands) to Sum Tat Ventures (STV, incorporated in the British Virgin Islands), a private company 100 per cent owned by Jimmy Lai.[[37]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-nextmedia_20160202-37) CWH was estimated to have net asset value of US$6.1 million. STV paid US$100 million in cash for 70 per cent stake of CWH. In 2013, STV paid another US$20 million for the remaining 30 per cent stake of CWH.[[37]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-nextmedia_20160202-37) CWH itself had its assets sold in 2011, and ceased operation in 2011. In total, STV paid US$120 million in cash for CWH. On Lai's Form 3B disclosure form, STV is listed as having the same correspondence address as Next Media in Hong Kong.[[38]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-38)

Near the end of 2013, Lai spent approximately US$73 million (or NT$2.3 billion) to purchase a 2 per cent stake (~17 million shares) in Taiwanese electronics manufacturer [HTC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTC "HTC").[[39]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-39)

### Activities in Myanmar

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jimmy_Lai&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Activities in Myanmar")]

In 2014, leaked documents showed Jimmy Lai paid former US deputy defence secretary and former World Bank president [Paul Wolfowitz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Wolfowitz "Paul Wolfowitz") US$75,000 for his help with projects in Myanmar. Lai also reportedly remitted approximately US$213,000 to businessman Phone Win, with whom Lai's Hong Kong-registered Best Combo company reportedly collaborated on Yangon real estate projects.[[40]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-40)

Lai pioneered a reader-centric philosophy with [paparazzi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paparazzi "Paparazzi") journalism in Hong Kong based on publications such as _[USA Today](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USA\_Today "USA Today")_ and _[The Sun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Sun\_(United\_Kingdom) "The Sun (United Kingdom)")_.[[41]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-41) His best-selling _Next Magazine_ and _Apple Daily_ newspaper featured a mix of racy tabloid material and news items oriented to the mass market with plenty of colour and graphics that attracted a wide range of readers, some of whom were also critics of Lai and his ideology.[[42]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-42)

### Hong Kong publications

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jimmy_Lai&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Hong Kong publications")]

Owing to the [1989 Tiananmen Square protests and massacre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1989_Tiananmen_Square_protests_and_massacre "1989 Tiananmen Square protests and massacre"), Lai became an advocate of democracy and critic of the People's Republic of China government.[[43]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-43) In 1990, he began publishing _[Next Magazine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next\_Magazine\_(Hong\_Kong\_and\_Taiwan) "Next Magazine (Hong Kong and Taiwan)")_, which combined tabloid sensationalism with hard-hitting political and business reporting.[[44]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-44) He proceeded to found other magazines, including _[Sudden Weekly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudden\_Weekly "Sudden Weekly")_ (忽然一週), _Eat & Travel Weekly_ (飲食男女), _Trading Express/Auto Express_ (交易通/搵車快線) and the youth-oriented _[Easy Finder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Easy\_Finder "Easy Finder")_ (壹本便利).[[45]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-45)

In 1995, as the [Hong Kong handover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handover_of_Hong_Kong "Handover of Hong Kong") approached, Lai founded _[Apple Daily](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple\_Daily "Apple Daily")_, a newspaper [start-up](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Startup_company "Startup company") that he financed with $100 million of his own money.[[46]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-46) The newspaper's circulation rose to 400,000 copies by 1997,[[47]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-47) which was the territory's second largest among 60 other newspapers.[[48]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-48) According to Lai, he aspired to maintain [freedom of speech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_speech "Freedom of speech") in Hong Kong through _Apple Daily_.[[49]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-49) In addition to promoting democracy, Lai's publications often ruffled feathers of fellow Hong Kong tycoons by exposing their personal foibles and relations with local government.[[50]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-50)

In 2003, ahead of the record-breaking pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong during July, the cover of _Next Magazine_ featured a photo-montage of the territory's embattled [chief executive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Executive_of_Hong_Kong "Chief Executive of Hong Kong")[Tung Chee-Hwa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tung_Chee-Hwa "Tung Chee-Hwa") taking a pie in the face. The magazine urged readers to take to the streets while _Apple Daily_ distributed stickers calling for Tung to resign.[[51]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-51)

In 2006, _Sudden Weekly_ and _Next Magazine_ ranked first and second in circulation for Hong Kong's magazine market.[[52]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-autogenerated1-52)_Apple Daily_ became the No. 2 newspaper in Hong Kong.[[52]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-autogenerated1-52)

In 2020, Lai launched an English version of _Apple Daily_.[[53]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-53)

### Taiwan publications

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jimmy_Lai&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Taiwan publications")]

Lai launched Taiwanese editions of _Next Magazine_ in 2001 and _Apple Daily_ in 2003, taking on heavily established rivals who made considerable effort to thwart him. Rival publishers pressed advertisers to boycott and distributors not to undertake home delivery. His Taiwan offices were vandalised on numerous occasions.[[54]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-54) As the publications grew to have the largest readership in their category, the advertising boycotts ended.[[52]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-autogenerated1-52)

In October 2006, Lai launched _[Sharp Daily](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharp\_Daily "Sharp Daily")_ (Shuang Bao in Mandarin), a free daily newspaper targeting Taipei commuters.[[55]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-55) The company also launched _Me! Magazine_ in Taiwan.[[56]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-56)

In building Taiwan's most popular newspaper, _Apple Daily_, and magazine, _Next Magazine_, Lai's racy publications were described as having a great impact on the country's hitherto staid media culture.[[57]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-57)

### Publication challenges

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jimmy_Lai&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Publication challenges")]

Lai's publications remained banned in China since their inception.[[23]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-:0-23) The ban originated from Lai's 1994 newspaper column, where he told [Premier of the PRC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premier_of_the_PRC "Premier of the PRC")[Li Peng](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Li_Peng "Li Peng"), seen as a driving force behind the Tiananmen Square crackdown, to "drop dead".[[58]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-58) He also called the [Chinese Communist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party "Chinese Communist Party") "a monopoly that charges a premium for lousy service".[[59]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-59) China's government retaliated against Lai by starting a shutdown of Giordano shops, prompting him to sell out of the company to save it.[[23]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-:0-23) In addition to having his publications banned in China, businesses had distanced themselves from placing advertisements in _Apple Daily_ to avoid retaliation from the Chinese government.[[60]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-60)[[61]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-61)

Lai had frequently faced hostility from the many Beijing-backed tycoons, including attempts to force supplier boycotts of his companies. Major Hong Kong property developers and top companies advertised only in competing publications not owned by Lai.[[62]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-62) He also faced a lengthy battle to list on the [Hong Kong Stock Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong_Stock_Exchange "Hong Kong Stock Exchange"), which Lai sidestepped through a [reverse takeover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_takeover "Reverse takeover"). He managed to list the company in 1999 by acquiring Paramount Publishing Group in October of that year.[[63]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-63)[[64]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-64)

In 2020, Apple Daily published a falsehood-ridden 64-page report produced by Typhoon Investigations alleging Joe Biden's son [Hunter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunter_Biden "Hunter Biden") had a "problematic" connection with the Chinese Communist Party, which was widely cited by far-right influencers such as [Steve Bannon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Bannon "Steve Bannon").[[65]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-65)[[66]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-66) An [NBC News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_News "NBC News") report linked the Typhoon Investigations to a fake "intelligence firm" and claimed that the author of the document, a self-identified Swiss security analyst named Martin Aspen, was a "fabricated identity". The original poster of the document, Christopher Balding, admitted that he wrote parts of the document and later stated that the document had been commissioned by _Apple Daily_.[[67]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-nbcnews_1245387-67) Lai later said that he had personally "nothing to do with" the report, but he admitted his senior executive, Mark Simon, had "worked with the project". Simon resigned following the NBC report and apologised for having "allowed damage to Jimmy on a matter he was completely in the dark on".[[68]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-theguardian_20201031_jimmy-68) The report was among many incidents many US democracy experts believe was instrumental in the cause of the [2021 Capitol attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack "January 6 United States Capitol attack") there.[[69]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-69) Lai admitted on 25 November 2024 that he told Cheung Kim-hung about featuring more negative news in an English edition of Apple Daily, which was launched in May 2020, about a month before the enactment of the Beijing-imposed security law.[[70]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-70)

Political activities
--------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jimmy_Lai&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Political activities")]

Lai is a longtime champion of the Hong Kong [pro-democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pro-democracy_camp_(Hong_Kong) "Pro-democracy camp (Hong Kong)") movement.[[71]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-time_5792171-71)[[72]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-bbc_51669453-72) According to Lai, _[The Road to Serfdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Road\_to\_Serfdom "The Road to Serfdom")_ by [Friedrich Hayek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Hayek "Friedrich Hayek") inspired him to fight for freedom.[[73]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-Gluckman-73) His advocacy had been expressed through his business ventures, such as distributing Giordano t-shirts with portraits of student leaders.[[74]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-74) His high-profile support for the pro-democracy movements came under strong condemnation from the Chinese government.[[75]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-75)[[12]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-The_Case_of_Jimmy_Lai-12) As the proprietor of one of few that journals that has remained staunchly supportive of the pro-democracy cause, challenging Chinese Communist Party rule, Lai is considered an "anti-China troublemaker".[[76]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-bbc_57578926-76) In May 2020, Lai told [CNN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN "CNN") that US president [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") was "the only one who can save us" from China, with Apple Daily publishing a similar plea addressed to Trump the same month.[[77]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-77) In the [2020 United States elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_elections "2020 United States elections"), Lai backed Trump, praising the latter for his "hardline approach" to Beijing.[[78]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-78)

On 13 December 2014, Lai was one of the pro-democracy leaders arrested during the clearance of the Admiralty protest site of the [Umbrella Movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Hong_Kong_protests "2014 Hong Kong protests"). On the following day, Lai announced he would step down as head of Next Media "to spend more time with his family and further pursue his personal interests."[[79]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-scmp_1678574-79)

Lai had been the target of hostile attacks and disturbances, including the leaving of machetes, axes and threatening messages in his driveway.[[80]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-bbc_30776405-80) He had been rammed by a car, and his home was firebombed several times, most recently in 2019.[[81]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-nytimes_20150112_firebombs-81)[[82]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-bloomberg_20190905_home-82) Lai's aide and Next Media spokesman Mark Simon condemned these attacks and stated, "This is a continual effort to intimidate the press in Hong Kong. This is raw and pure intimidation."[[83]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-83) Some activists felt that the [Hong Kong Police Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong_Police_Force "Hong Kong Police Force") and the [Hong Kong government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_Hong_Kong "Government of Hong Kong"), which have been Chinese-controlled since the [handover in 1997](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_of_sovereignty_over_Hong_Kong "Transfer of sovereignty over Hong Kong"), did not always follow up on these misconducts against Lai, and that culprits are rarely found.[[84]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-reuters1-84)

During the early hours of 12 January 2015, two masked men hurled petrol bombs at Lai's home on Kadoorie Avenue in [Kowloon Tong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kowloon_Tong "Kowloon Tong"). At the same time, a petrol bomb was thrown at the [Next Media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next_Media "Next Media") headquarters in [Tseung Kwan O Industrial Estate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tseung_Kwan_O_Industrial_Estate "Tseung Kwan O Industrial Estate").[[85]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-85) The fires were extinguished by security guards. The perpetrators fled and two cars used in the attacks were found torched in [Shek Kip Mei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shek_Kip_Mei "Shek Kip Mei") and [Cheung Sha Wan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheung_Sha_Wan "Cheung Sha Wan"). The crimes were denounced as an "attack on press freedom".[[79]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-scmp_1678574-79)

### National security law and prosecution

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jimmy_Lai&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: National security law and prosecution")]

[![Image 5](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Next_Media_Company_Limited_%28revised%29.jpg/250px-Next_Media_Company_Limited_%28revised%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Next_Media_Company_Limited_(revised).jpg)

Next Digital offices, raided by police on 10 August 2020

On 30 June 2020, the [Hong Kong national security law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Hong_Kong_national_security_law "2020 Hong Kong national security law") was enacted by China's parliament, by-passing the [Legislative Council of Hong Kong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legislative_Council_of_Hong_Kong "Legislative Council of Hong Kong"). Before the law was enacted, Lai called it "a death knell for Hong Kong" and alleged that it would destroy the territory's rule of law.[[96]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-20200810arrest-96)

On 10 August 2020, Lai was arrested at his home for alleged collusion with foreign forces (a crime under the new national security law) and fraud. Other Next Digital staff were also arrested, and police searched the home of both Lai and his son.[[96]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-20200810arrest-96) Later in the morning, approximately 200 Hong Kong police officers raided the offices of _Apple Daily_ in Tseung Kwan O Industrial Estate, seizing around 25 boxes of materials.[[97]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-HKMAOapplauds-97)[HSBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HSBC "HSBC") took the step to freeze his bank account.[[98]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-98)

After Lai was arrested, the stock price of [Next Digital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next_Digital "Next Digital") rose as high as 331 per cent on 11 August.[[99]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-99) Bail was set at HK$300,000 (approx. US$38,705), with a [surety](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surety "Surety") of HK$200,000 (approx. US$25,803). _Apple Daily_ said that more than 500,000 copies of its subsequent day's paper were printed, five times the usual number.[[100]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-:1-100) The front page of Apple Daily showed an image of Lai in handcuffs with the headline: "Apple Daily must fight on."[[100]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Lai#cite_note-:1-100)
